text: while the government has issued new
guidelines on making workplaces safe
including observing the 2 meter social
distancing where possible and minimizing
risk where it's not possible workers in
industries such as construction and
manufacturing who can't work from home
as we said are being encouraged to go to
work this week though preferably not by
public transport and union leaders have
cautiously welcomed the guidance though
they still have concerns as our business
editor
Simon Jack tells us wake up time for the
economy here at this bed and mattress
Factory in Cambridgeshire activity is
stirring slowly back into life
sixty-eight workers out of a normal 300
have volunteered to come back to work
sue is one of the team leaders seen
friends colleagues and their and the day
goes quicker than being at home doing
the thing working with a skeleton crew
like this means it's mostly possible to
keep your social distance but not all
the time some workers need protective
equipment and Benson's operations
manager says that getting back to full
swing will require more radical changes
we may have no other option if demand
continues to grow and we ever need to
get back to full or close to full
capacity but to introduce shift work
because we cannot work as we were in the
past with a full shift everybody working
close together we can't maintain social
distancing where social distancing is
not possible it advises back-to-back
side-by-side working or the use of masks
it suggests working in fixed teams to
avoid mixing groups of personnel
avoiding public transport where possible
while staggering arrival and break times
constructions also on the list of
industries being encouraged to get
workers back on the job
outdoor work is considered less risky
and many sites like this one in Bristol
have been back at work for weeks but the
boss of Bedfordshire based story homes
so that if workers and subcontractors
didn't obey the rules the consequences
could be swift and severe everybody has
to reduce them otherwise they will be
asked to leave site and may not be asked
to return
so people's livelihoods depend on them
working in construction if you don't
work you don't earn no one is just
popping the champagne corks and saying
we're all coming back on Monday
everybody's being very very sensible
about the last 24 hours have arguably
placed more responsibility and more
discretion in the hands of employers and
that concerns unions we're saying that
they shouldn't be pressured into going
back to work and they should refuse and
we will obviously defend them
it is a slow and tentative green light
for small parts of the economy but with
a warning that if infection rates begin
to accelerate the brakes go back on
Simon Jack BBC News
well many businesses on the high street
are still not able to open for many
weeks possibly months business owners
say that they still have unanswered
questions about the circumstances in
which they might be able to reopen our
business correspondent Emma Simpson has
been to st. Albans to speak to some of
them our high streets have been deserted
for seven weeks now the reopening still
on pause here in st. Albans the owners
behind these shop fronts are now
thinking about the road ahead and
they've more questions than answers like
David and Sarah at the jewellery shop
we're very worried about the basics of
actually basically serving people so
sitting down six feet away is not ideal
in a jewellery shop we're very used to
getting up close and personal measuring
a finger maybe attaching a necklace
around a lady's neck to do very touching
pair of earrings mark and Sophie run the
hairdresser's they along with Beauty
Salons won't be reopening until July at
the earliest childcare is a big worry
for this family business oldest son is
at school my daughter is at nursery and
we don't know what the situation is with
that opening and we have grandparents
but they're in the age category where we
shouldn't really be exposing them for us
to open it's worthless unless I can
ensure that both of my children are
looked after
Sean runs three pubs in st. Albans
doesn't know when he will reopen he says
he can't follow the rules on social
distancing because he needs his pops
fool to survive without that we cannot
trade so we have an option be shut and
that's it
and we never reopen or we try and you
know develop something that we can
continue on but to do that we are going
to need a hell of a lot of government
support there is a lot for businesses to
digest tonight the government says
they'll have to be innovative in getting
back to work there's certainly a
willingness to do that here
there's even an idea to pedestrian eyes
the city center to coax people back
Helen and Andrew run a bridle and
menswear business like everything else
weddings have been put on hold
biggest worry is not having the clients
come back because they've been so used
to being at home we're all different
businesses on this street but we are all
interlinked and if people don't come out
and spend their money we we're basically
that's a way to have to shut they're
desperate to reopen but for now these
owners will have to wait nobody knows
when our high streets will be crowded
again
Emma Simpson BBC News sent Albans
